contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish|Menesthius}} '''Menestheus''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Μενεσθεύς), the son of Peteus, son of [[Orneus]], son of [[Erechtheus]], and either Polyxene or Mnesimache,<ref>[[Tzetzes]], ''Homeric Allegories'', Prologue, 554 - 555</ref> was a legendary [[King of Athens]] during the [[Trojan War]]. He was set up as king by the [[Dioscuri]] when [[Theseus]] travelled to the underworld, and at his return Menestheus exiled him from the city.<ref>[[Plutarch]], ''Theseus'', 32. 1 ff</ref><ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 1. 17. 5</ref><ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'', [[Epitome]] of Book 4, 1. 23</ref> Menestheus was one of the suitors of [[Helen of Troy]],<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 3. 10. 8</ref> and when the [[Trojan War]] started he brought "fifty black ships" to [[Troy]].<ref>[[Homer]], ''Iliad'', 2. 557</ref><ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 97</ref> In the ''[[Iliad]]'' it is noted that no one could arrange chariots and shield-bearing warriors in battle orders better than Menestheus, and that only [[Nestor]] could vie with him in that respect.<ref>''Iliad'', 2. 552 ff</ref> Yet further he is characterized as not valiant. When [[Agamemnon]] was reviewing his troops he found Menestheus in the back rows seemingly avoiding action.<ref>''Il.'' 4. 327</ref> Later when [[Sarpedon]] attacked the portion of the Greek wall that he was in charge of, Menestheus shivered and had to call on [[Telamonian Aias]] and [[Teucer]] for aid.<ref>''Il.'' 12. 331 ff</ref> Menestheus was one of the warriors in the [[Trojan Horse]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 1. 23. 8</ref><ref>[[Quintus Smyrnaeus]], ''Fall of Troy'', 12. 314</ref> After Troy was sacked, he sailed to [[Karaburun|Mimas]], then to [[Melos]] where he became king.<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'', [[Epitome]] of Book 4, 6. 15b = [[Tzetzes]] on [[Lycophron]], 911</ref> When Menestheus died, Athens passed back to the family of [[Theseus]].<ref>[[Plutarch]], ''Theseus'', 35. 5</ref> The name '''Menestheus''' may also refer to: *Menestheus, son of Clytius and grandson of [[Aeolus]], a companion of [[Aeneas]]<ref>[[Virgil]], ''Aeneid'', 10. 129</ref> *Menestheus, a warrior in the army of the [[Seven Against Thebes]], participant of the disk-trowing competition at the funeral games of [[Opheltes]]<ref>[[Statius]], ''Thebaid'', 6. 661</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Start box}} {{s-reg}} {{Succession box| title=[[King of Athens]] | before=[[Theseus]] | after=[[Demophon (King of Athens)|Demophon]]| years= }} {{End box}} {{Characters in the Iliad}} [[Category:Characters in the Iliad]] [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Kings of Athens]] [[Category:Mythological kings]] [[Category:People of the Trojan War]] {{Greek-myth-stub}}
